The focus of the trial was something they called ICE, the Iraqi Currency Exchange, where the old Saddam Hussein dinars were gathered up and incinerated, and new currency was put into all the banks all around Iraq in a very short period of time.
And they needed camps to house the workers and to be headquarters for where the trucks would do all this driving.
These guys built the camps in a big hurry, within a month or six weeks late in the summer of 2003.
And they had to keep these camps going and feed everyone, and provide the vehicles, and that sort of thing.
So what did they do that was fraudulent?

Well, the jury believed the charge of the two whistleblowers, one guy a subcontractor for Custer Battles and the other an employee, that they created a number of subsidiary companies in the Cayman Islands.
Bill mills is what the lawyer for the accusers called them.
And used these entities to draw up fake invoices from whole cloth; sometimes for several tens of thousands of dollars.
Some of them for 1.2 million and very large amounts like that.

One of the dramatic allegations that came up in the trial that the jury accepted completely was that a particular invoice contained one line item for a bunch of forklifts to be leased to the CPA, to the American-led occupation authority.
And it turns out that these forklifts had been swiped from the now defunct civilian Iraqi Airline at Baghdad International Airport, where Custer Battles had another job going on.
The forklifts were swiped.
They were painted blue and leased at the cost of some hundreds of thousands of dollars back to the CPA, and then billed for these large amounts of money.
Now, how did Custer Battles explain these actions?
Well, the defense said, in general, that this entire misadventure was the product of confusion during a chaotic wartime moment.
It was the product, too, they say of spite.
They charged that Mr. Baldwin and Mr. Isaacson were disgruntled former employees who turned around and sued them and tried to blow the whistle on a perfectly legitimate piece of work.
And there was testimony that they did an okay job on setting up these camps for the currency exchange.
Now, this was the first case of war profiteering in Iraq to go to trial.
Do you think there will be others?

Well, there's one case that we know is on the conveyor belt towards trial in this very same courtroom; $16 million in allegedly false claims, again by Custer Battles, against the Coalition Provisional Authority for a different contract.
This was their contract to provide security at the civilian side of Baghdad International Airport after the fall of Saddam Hussein.
The charge is that at a time when they didn't have much work to do, because the airport was shut down, too dangerous, they were double and triple billing the government for what they weren't doing.
John Mulligan is a reporter with the Providence Journal.

A Friday deadline set by the Trump administration to strike a deal renegotiating NAFTA came and went, with talks set to resume this week.
One area of the trade deal concerns automobiles, which are manufactured through a complex web of parts suppliers and employees in Canada, the U.S.
and Mexico.
Paul Eisenstein is publisher of thedetroitbureau.com.
It's a website that covers the auto industry.
And he joins us now.
Paul, welcome to the program.
Good to be with you.
What do the proposed changes to NAFTA mean for the auto industry overall?
Well, I think the best thing that you can say about it is that it will prevent the Trump administration from eliminating NAFTA entirely.
Unfortunately, we still can't tell what the final results will be because we don't have a deal, from what we hear, with Canada.
And I think we're still trying to figure out exactly what the negotiations so far have resulted in when it comes to Mexico.
There are going to be new caps, new rules - supposedly going to help drive a few more jobs back to the United States.
But one thing that I'm particularly concerned about from what I've gotten out of the deal so far is that we'll probably also see prices for American consumers go up on cars over the next few years.
Does it seem to you that they're kind of tinkering around the edges?

I mean, when they're talking about things like increasing the percentage of parts of a vehicle that have to be made in the United States, are these fundamental changes or just a way for the administration to say, hey, we took a hard line, and we got a new deal?
I think a lot of it is to say, we took a hard line, and look what we did.
There's some indication that automakers and auto parts suppliers could wind up rushing to put new plants down in Mexico before the deal officially takes effect.
You know, it's one of those things you do.
You move things around when you're about to sign an armistice over war.
Well, the same thing happens here.
And we might wind up actually seeing some jobs go to Mexico before this goes into effect.
Interesting.
Let's talk about the supply chain and consider one specific vehicle in particular, the Ford F-150 pickup truck.
It's called one of the most made-in-America vehicles.
But if you look at the components, it's made using aluminum from Quebec, windshield wipers from Mexico, transmissions from the U.S.
Is that a typical supply chain in North America?
Oh, that's very much the case.
You can take it down literally to the nuts and bolts.

You may have a screw produce at a plant, say, in Indiana that's shipped across the border and used in a module that then is shipped across the border again and installed into a bigger part, installed in something else and then finally returned to the United States and assembled into a Ford F-Series.
Some of the parts could cross the border, I've been told, as much as seven times before it rolls off the assembly line.
I was surprised, Paul, to learn that the largest exporter of cars from the United States is not an American company.
Well, thanks for letting me get in your business.
No - no, you're fine.
Because, Congressman, this is the question that has come up over and over again on the debate stage and that a lot of people are interested in.
The people who say that they support single-payer - how do you bring the costs down?
So the question is, how do you with your dual system get the objective that we're looking for here?
Professor Posner, you wrote a couple of months ago that this trial is like a certain kind of detective novel.
I quote, ""We know who did it, we know how it all will end.
The only mystery is how we will get there."" From what's happened so far, are we getting there through a process that's recognizable to you as criminal justice?
Well, yes, it's recognizable as criminal justice.
We have a trial and charges have been filed and now we're hearing testimony.
We won't know for quite a long time whether the trial is successful or a failure, but it does resemble a trial as it is supposed to.
One of the questions you've raised about this trial is the implications for the Baathist subordinates of Saddam Hussein.
Well, the question is whether they are going to throw their lot in with the constitutional settlement or whether they're going to continue to resist and support the insurgency.

So the concern I expressed in that Op-Ed was that if they thought that the crimes the trial was adjudicating were defined broadly enough, then they could expect at some point in the future to be indicted and punished.
And if they expect that, they're not going to be willing to lay down their arms and join into the political process.
So a political challenge that you see implicit at least in the proceeding.

Professor Diane Orentlicher, do you see, first of all, a criminal justice proceeding here as opposed to a political one, and do you see the problem posed in terms of what the former subordinates of Saddam Hussein make of all this?
Well, yes, this certainly is a criminal justice process that is taking place, however, in an extremely volatile political context.

As far as implications for lower-level perpetrators, I don't see the legal theories of criminal responsibility coming out of this trial as being that important to how we address the insurgency threat.
I think there are much more important tools for addressing that threat.
Is justice served by only having a couple of dozen trials of leading Baathists as opposed to large numbers of people who took part in these operations?
Well, in my view, it's important, certainly for Iraqis, that at least those who are seen as most responsible be prosecuted.
Whether that will be enough is a difficult question.
And I think Iraqis understand right now how difficult it is even to put on trial those who are most responsible, and so may be willing to accept that prosecutions have to stop with the top leaders.
I'd like to ask you the first witness whose testimony was heard in this case--not today, but in the previous session--actually has since died.
I don't believe that he was cross-examined.
And he described the massacre of people at the town of Dujail, which is the crime for which Saddam Hussein is being tried.
But he had nothing to say whatever about Saddam Hussein's culpability.
This raised the possibility at least that there might be a weak case presented against Saddam Hussein.
Is it conceivable to you, Professor Posner, that this trial could result in the acquittal of Saddam Hussein in what happened that day?
I think it's extremely difficult to imagine that that would happen for two reasons.
First, the evidence against him is quite strong, and you don't want to evaluate the whole case on the basis of just one piece of testimony.

But second, the political pressure to convict and punish him is overwhelming, and I just can't imagine that the judges would resist it even if they thought that he deserved acquittal, which is also hard to imagine.
You feel comfortable with that second judgment, that the political pressure for a conviction is intensive?
If Saddam Hussein's lawyers were here, they would say that's the whole problem, it's a political event.
It is a political event, but I think what's important is that the trial be and look fair to the extent that circumstances allow.
No one can say that a conviction and punishment would be unfair even if some elements of the process itself are unfair.
Diane Orentlicher, do you have the same view of fairness and the appearance of fairness in this trial?
Well, I think that in the long term for Iraq, and in the short term for the rest of the world, the appearance of fairness will be all important for the credibility of this trial process.
There is absolutely a strong clamor for justice among Iraqis right now and the judges are acutely aware of that.
But they are also acutely aware of the long-term importance of a fair trial process, and you see that dynamic playing out every single minute in the courtroom.
You see the judge trying to control Saddam Hussein on the one hand, but also making absolutely sure that he receives fair representation.
So I think that the appearance of justice is very important, not just to the international community, but to the Iraqi judges and public.

So implicit in this trial, perhaps, to an Iraqi audience is this is the kind of trial that you, as a citizen in the new Iraq, might be able to expect--have your own lawyer, you're allowed to assert your rights in court.
And this is a feature not just making peace with the old Iraq, but this is a feature of the new Iraq that we're trying to create here.
That's a theory.

That's the justification that's given for this trial, and I would add to it the idea that you can be punished for committing a crime that's been defined in advance by some kind of democratic body, and you cannot be punished simply because you're an opponent of the regime.
Of course, there's an irony here because Saddam is, in a way, being punished in part because he's an opponent.
And that creates a great deal of tension which Saddam and his lawyers are exploiting every time they argue that the tribunal is illegitimate, that the judges are pawns of the Americans and so forth.
Professor Eric Posner of the University of Chicago and Diane Orentlicher of American University, thank you both very much for talking with us today.
Happy to be here.
Thank you.
